item.title: Do pandemics in fiction still work?
item.description: We're living in a global pandemic. And pandemics, plagues, and apocalypses have always been part of our fiction. Entertainment might need to change the way it portrays those events, to adjust to our new sense of vulnerability.

item.title: Oligarchy or corporate control?
item.description: In the 1920s and 1930s the US reacted to break up the monopoly and oligopoly of the "robber barons". The government had the will, and the public backing, to make changes necessary to protect from corporate dominance. That will doesn't exist any more.

item.title: Science fiction or fantasy?
item.description: For some reason, these two genres are always placed together. There's not a great deal that actually connects them, though. One envisions possible futures, things that might be. The other deliberately looks beyonds the bounds of even potential reality.

item.title: The emotional connection of the 1980s
item.description: The 1980s maintains a strong hold on our culture. It's reminisced about, idealized, dramatized, and remembered in fiction and in documentaries. Why does it have such a strong emotional hold?

item.title: Drama, familiarity, and repetition
item.description: What makes something dramatic? It is less a case that some things are inherently dramatic, and more that drama stems from unfamiliarity, shock, or strangeness. Variety is dramatic.

item.title: Thoughts on cyberpunk
item.description: Reflections on what cyberpunk stories written today are supposed to look like. When the real world replicates the dystopian visions of 1980s cyberpunk fiction, what does the genre do today?
